Daniel Lambert, famed as the heaviest man of his age, died in Stamford in 1809 and soon became the subject of tall tales—fighting bears, walls knocked down to remove his body, and poems he supposedly wrote. His name entered popular lore as a byword for immense size, and remains part of Stamford’s local identity

The familiar tale of Newton discovering gravity under an apple tree likely has a kernel of truth — he did say that watching an apple fall in Woolsthorpe helped spark the idea — but the detail of it striking his head is later embellishment. The famous tree still survives (in replanted form) at Woolsthorpe Manor, and the embellished anecdote now functions almost like a modern folk legend around a scientific figure

column3: The Leaning Tower of Dry Doddington
column5: Dry Doddington’s medieval church has a tower that leans more dramatically than Pisa’s, and because no one knows when or why it tilted, locals have supplied their own explanations. Some say plague burials disturbed the ground; others claim the church was built on a pagan mound
